summary: This is the U.S. Government's memorandum in support of pretrial detention for Ghislaine Maxwell, arguing she is an extreme flight risk due to the seriousness of the charges, strength of evidence, her international citizenship, significant financial resources, and lack of ties to the United States. It details the charges against her for conspiring with Jeffrey Epstein to sexually abuse minors between 1994 and 1997.

persons.name: Ghislaine Maxwell
persons.context: Charged with conspiracy to entice and transport minors for illegal sex acts and perjury, alleged to have been Jeffrey Epstein's closest associate in grooming and abusing underage girls.

persons.name: Jeffrey Epstein
persons.context: Described as a serial sexual predator with whom Maxwell partnered to exploit and abuse young girls at his properties.

persons.name: Audrey Strauss
persons.context: Signed the government's detention memorandum as the Acting U.S. Attorney for the Southern District of New York.

connections.description: Partners in a scheme to sexually abuse underage girls; Maxwell was one of Epstein's closest associates and played a key role in identifying, grooming, and facilitating abuse.
Between 2007 and 2011, approximately more than $20 million was transferred from accounts associated with Epstein to accounts associated with Maxwell.

events.title: Period of Alleged Abuse
events.description: Maxwell and Epstein allegedly conspired to sexually abuse underage girls at Epstein's properties in New York, Florida, and New Mexico.

events.title: Maxwell's Deposition Testimony
events.description: Maxwell gave deposition testimony in a civil lawsuit in the Southern District of New York, where she allegedly lied under oath about her role in facilitating the abuse of minors.

events.title: Sale of NYC Residence
events.description: Maxwell sold a New York City residence for $15 million through an LLC, with over $14 million deposited into an account in her name.

events.title: Epstein Indictment Unsealed
events.description: After the indictment against Jeffrey Epstein was unsealed, Maxwell went into hiding, stopped public appearances, and took steps to avoid detection.

events.title: Purchase of New Hampshire Property
events.description: A 156-acre property in Bradford, New Hampshire, was acquired in an all-cash purchase through an anonymized LLC, where Maxwell was reportedly hiding.

events.title: Maxwell Indictment Returned
events.description: A federal grand jury returned a sealed indictment charging Maxwell with multiple counts related to enticing minors for sex acts and perjury.

keyFacts: Ghislaine Maxwell is charged with conspiracy to entice and transport minors for illegal sex acts (1994-1997) and two counts of perjury from her 2016 deposition.

The government argues Maxwell is an extreme flight risk due to her citizenship in the U.S., U.K., and France; possession of three passports; significant financial resources (including accounts holding up to $20 million); and lack of meaningful ties to the U.S.
Between 2007 and 2011, over $20 million was transferred from Jeffrey Epstein's accounts to accounts associated with Maxwell.

After Epstein's indictment was unsealed in July 2019, Maxwell went into hiding, moved locations, changed contact information, and was found on a 156-acre property in New Hampshire purchased anonymously in December 2019.
The government identifies multiple victims, some as young as 14, whose accounts are corroborated by flight records, diary entries, business records, and other evidence.
